commitMessage:
fix(status): Production Ready indicator now correctly shows โ for shipped features

## What Changed
- Simplified checkProductionReady() method in src/commands/status.ts (15 lines โ 3 lines)
- Replaced broken validation-results.json parsing with delegation to checkShipped()
- Added 3 new smoke tests verifying all behavioral expectations (52 lines)
- Modified 11 files with 366 insertions, 34 deletions

**Root Cause**: The status command tried to read validation-results.json expecting
a Record<string, {passed: boolean}> format, but the actual file is an array with
no "passed" field. This caused checkProductionReady() to always return false, even
for successfully shipped features.

**Solution**: Use ship-record.json as single source of truth. The checkProductionReady()
method now delegates to checkShipped(), establishing ship-record.json with
validationPassed:true as the definitive proof of production readiness.

## Why This Change
Fixed confusing UX where `/status` showed "โ Production Ready" for features that had
already shipped successfully. This broke user trust in the status command and created
uncertainty about whether features were actually ready for production.

The fix aligns with semantic correctness: "Production Ready" means "passed all gates
and can go to production", which is exactly what ship-record.json certifies.

## Impact
- Users now see consistent status indicators (both Production Ready โ and Shipped โ together)
- Eliminates confusion about production readiness state
- Single source of truth reduces maintenance burden
- Simplified codebase (removed 15 lines of broken parsing logic)
- "Harden โ" indicator already shows hardening completion, so no loss of granularity

Test Results:
- All 1367 tests passing (3 new tests added)
- Zero TypeScript errors
- Zero ESLint errors
- 0% code duplication
- All quality gates green
